info.title: About Electricity Maps
info.text: is an API platform providing real-time and predictive electricity signals allowing any device to reduce their cost and emissions by informing them about the best time to consume electricity.

and how much CO2 was emitted to produce it

more-options-dropdown.summary: Discover real-time electricity insights with the Electricity Maps app!

new-feature-popover.title: New feature: 72-hour view
new-feature-popover.content: Explore trends in live and historical data with the new 72-hour window.

view1.text:
Here you can explore the climate impact of electricity for many countries globally.

Let us guide you through our map in a few simple steps!

view2.header: See how much CO2 is emitted to produce your electricity, in real-time
view2.text: We color areas around the world by the carbon intensity of consumed electricity (includes all greenhouse gases). The greener the color, the more climate-friendly the electricity.

view3.header: Know where your electricity comes from
view3.text: Arrows on the map indicate flows of electricity between different areas. Click on an area to see more information about the origins of its electricity.

view4.text: Toggle between Electricity Production and Consumption, as well as Country or Zone views and discover real-time insights into global energy dynamics and make informed choices for a sustainable future.

view5.header: Switch between electricity and emissions views
view5.text: Toggle to alternate between charts that display a zone's electricity information or carbon emissions. The values shown represent the total for the selected period, and the information aligns with the chosen production or consumption mode.

view6.text: In the bottom left, you can view both real-time and past emission and electricity data all around the world. Change the aggregated data using the toggles or browse through the timeline to see the changes over time.

view7.text: Wind and solar energy production depend on the weather. Press the sun and wind buttons to display the real-time strength of wind and sunshine throughout the world.

country-panel.noDataAtTimestamp: Data is temporarily unavailable for the selected time
country-panel.noLiveData: Live data is temporarily unavailable for this area

disabledPriceReasons.licensing: Electricity prices are unavailable for this area due to licensing terms

country-panel.emissionFactorDataSourcesTooltip: Electricity production emission factors can originate from multiple sources. This happens as several factors, like plant-specific data, generation and sometimes fallback sources, are considered in emission calculations.
country-panel.disabledBreakdownChartReason: Disabled for the consumption view. Please switch to the production view to enable the origin chart
country-panel.dataIsDelayed: Data for this region can be up to {{hours}} hours delayed. Live data cannot be displayed.
country-panel.dataIsEstimated: Some of the data for this region is estimated. Read more about our estimation methodology here.
country-panel.exchangesAreMissing: This chart does not include exchange data. Exchanges are visible in hourly views. Read more about our historical aggregations here.
country-panel.estimatedTooltip: The real-time data for this zone is estimated based on data from the source and the assumptions of the model.
country-panel.aggregatedTooltip: The data for this zone is aggregated based on historical hourly values
country-panel.helpUs: Help us identify the problem by taking a look at the runtime logs or contact the data provider.
country-panel.noParserInfo:
We do not yet have any information about this area.
Want to help fix this? You can contribute by adding area data.
country-panel.aggregationDisabled: Data is not available for the selected time period due to missing granular breakdown. Try a broader time period.
country-panel.fullyDisabled: The data we have available for this zone is insufficient and therefore not shown. If you are aware of data sources for this area, please let us know.

price-chart.price-disclaimer: All prices are per MWh, excl. taxes & grid fees.

feedback-card.title: Help us improve!
feedback-card.success-message: Your response helps us understand and improve the quality of our app.

estimations.subtitle: Please rate the following statement.
estimations.secondary-question: Anything we can do to improve it?
estimations.primary-question: The description of the data estimation was easy to understand:

feedback-card.primary-question: How would you rate your overall satisfaction with the Electricity Maps app?

ESTIMATED_FORECASTS_HIERARCHY.title: Data is estimated
ESTIMATED_FORECASTS_HIERARCHY.body: The data for this zone is estimated using a combination of internal and external production forecasts and Time Slicer Averages. This aims to provide a more accurate representation than Time Slicer Average alone but the data may still be subject to inaccuracies. The data will be updated as soon as real-time data becomes available.

ESTIMATED_TIME_SLICER_AVERAGE.title: Data is preliminary
ESTIMATED_TIME_SLICER_AVERAGE.body: The data provider is not reporting data for this hour. The displayed values are estimated based on historical measurements and will be updated once measured data is available. Note that estimated values may not account for real-time weather events.

ESTIMATED_MODE_BREAKDOWN.title: Data is partially estimated
ESTIMATED_MODE_BREAKDOWN.body: Electricity generation data for this zone is incomplete; missing values have been calculated using an estimation model.

ESTIMATED_RECONSTRUCT_BREAKDOWN.title: Data is always estimated
ESTIMATED_RECONSTRUCT_BREAKDOWN.body: The published data for this zone only provides the total production. Renewable sources are estimated using live weather data, while the fossil sources are deducted based on historical data for each production source.

estimated_generic_method.title: Data is estimated
estimated_generic_method.body: The published data for this zone is unavailable or incomplete. The data shown on the map is estimated using our best effort, but might differ from the actual values.

ESTIMATED_CONSTRUCT_BREAKDOWN.title: Data is always estimated
ESTIMATED_CONSTRUCT_BREAKDOWN.body: The data for this zone is not published in realtime and only provides the total production. Both hourly production and production sources are estimated based on historical data for each production source.

ESTIMATED_CONSTRUCT_ZERO_BREAKDOWN.title: Data is always estimated
ESTIMATED_CONSTRUCT_ZERO_BREAKDOWN.body: The data for this zone is not published in realtime and only provides the total production. Both hourly production and production sources are estimated based on historical data for each production source.

ESTIMATED_GENERAL_PURPOSE_ZONE_MODEL.title: Data is always estimated
ESTIMATED_GENERAL_PURPOSE_ZONE_MODEL.body: Real-time source data for this zone is not available. Current values are modelled using a combination of live weather data and historical production data.

threshold_filtered.title: Missing data
threshold_filtered.body: The data provider for this zone has been missing data for a prolonged period. We are monitoring the issue and will update the zone as soon as the data meets our quality threshold again.

aggregated.title: Data is aggregated
aggregated.body: The data consists of an aggregation of hourly values.

aggregated_estimated.title: Data is aggregated
aggregated_estimated.body: The data consists of an aggregation of hourly values. {{percentage}}% of the production values are estimated.

country-history.not-enough-data: Not enough data available to display chart
country-history.exchange-delay: Exchange data may be delayed by up to 48h.

zoneHeader.carbonIntensity: Grams of CO2 equivalent per kilowatt-hour (gCO2eq/kWh) measuring the greenhouse gas emissions from generating electricity

tooltips.weatherDisabled: Weather data is not available at this time

tooltips.aggregateInfo: Toggle between a granular zone view and an aggregated country view

misc.maintitle: Live 24/7 CO‚ÇÇ emissions of electricity consumption
misc.slow-loading-text: Still loading, if this continues try reloading...

emissionsAvailableIn: of emissions from electricity available in

theMap.mapColors-question: What do the colors on the map mean?
theMap.mapColors-answer: We color areas on the map by the amounts of greenhouse gases that is emitted for each unit of electricity consumed there (its carbon intensity). The greener the colour, the more climate-friendly the electricity consumption.
theMap.mapArrows-question: What do the arrows between areas on the map indicate?
theMap.mapArrows-answer: Arrows between the areas indicate the physical flow (imports and exports) of electricity between areas: the faster they blink, the faster the flow. The flow of electricity is important, because when you import some of your electricity from neighboring areas, you are also importing the carbon emissions associated with its production.
theMap.mapSolarWindButtons-question: What do ‚Äúsun‚Äù and ‚Äúwind‚Äù buttons on the map do?
theMap.mapSolarWindButtons-answer: These buttons toggle the display of real-time wind speeds and sunshine strength, giving an indication of the potential for transitioning to solar and wind based energy alternatives in different areas. Note that this is just a superficial indication, as the actual potential in installing wind turbines and solar cells is also dependent on many other factors.
theMap.mapNuclearColors-question: Why are nuclear-powered countries shown as green on the map?
theMap.mapNuclearColors-answer: Nuclear energy production has a very low carbon intensity (source), and nuclear-powered countries are therefore shown as green on the map. This does not mean that there are not other environmental challenges associated with nuclear energy (as is also the case with other forms of energy production), but these challenges are unrelated to the emissions of greenhouse gases and are therefore outside the scope of this map.
theMap.mapColorBlind-question: I am color blind. How can I read your map?
theMap.mapColorBlind-answer: You can change the colours displayed in the map by enabling the ‚Äúcolor blind mode‚Äù setting. It is located on right side of the app on desktop and in the settings panel on the mobile app.

mapAreas.noData-question: Why is data for my area not available?
mapAreas.noData-answer: Either because the area's data sources are temporarily unavailable, or because we do not yet have any data sources setup for the area. You can help us find new data sources.
mapAreas.whySmallAreas-question: Why do you divide the world into smaller areas and not simply show country averages?
mapAreas.whySmallAreas-answer: The areas are the smallest geographical areas we have data for. By having access to information at the highest level of granularity, electricity consumers in different areas can have a more precise knowledge about the origin of the electricity they are consuming, and its associated climate impact.
mapAreas.divideExistingArea-question: Can you divide my area into smaller parts?
mapAreas.divideExistingArea-answer: Sure, if there exists separate data sources for each part of the area. You can help us with adding new data sources
mapAreas.seeHistoricalData-question: Can I see the history for an area further back in time than 24 hours?
mapAreas.seeHistoricalData-answer: You can purchase access to all of our historical data through our database.

methodology.carbonIntensity-answer:
Carbon intensity is a measure of the greenhouse gas emissions associated with producing the electricity you consume (in gCO‚ÇÇeq/kWh - grams of carbon dioxide equivalents emitted per kilowatt hour of electricity consumed).

We measure the emissions of electricity consumption (not production), meaning all greenhouse gas emissions (both CO‚ÇÇ and other greenhouse gases such as methane) that has gone into producing the electricity which is being consumed in an area, taking into account the carbon intensities of the electricity imported from other areas. We use a life cycle analysis (LCA) approach, meaning that we take into account emissions arising from the whole life cycle of power plants (construction, fuel production, operational emissions, and decommissioning).
methodology.methodology-question: How did you calculate the numbers?
methodology.methodology-answer: We have detailed our full methodology on electricitymaps.com/methodology, with additional documentation in our GitHub Wiki.
methodology.regionalEmissionFactors-question: Why are the emission factors changing for different areas?
methodology.regionalEmissionFactors-answer: For some zones, we are able to source more precise emission factors than the global average used as a fallback. For example, for the US and the EU direct power plant emissions are publicly available. We then match these emissions with power plant generation data and compute per power plant emission factors, which is aggregated at a zone level. See details on the Wiki.
methodology.renewableLowCarbonDifference-question: What is the difference between ‚Äúrenewable‚Äù and ‚Äúlow-carbon‚Äù?
methodology.renewableLowCarbonDifference-answer: Renewable energy production is based on renewable energy sources such as wind and water flow, sunshine, and geothermal energy. Low-carbon energy production means that the production involves a very low level of greenhouse gas emissions, such as in nuclear power production.
methodology.importsAndExports-question: Do you take into account imports and exports of electricity?
methodology.importsAndExports-answer: Yes, we do. Imports and exports can be seen on the map as small arrows between different areas when consumption mode is selected. Detailed information can be seen in the charts shown when you click on an area.
methodology.emissionsOfStored-question: What about emissions from generating electricity which is then stored in batteries or used to fill reservoirs?
methodology.emissionsOfStored-answer: As currently only a small proportion of electricity is stored, inaccuracies in the modelling of these emissions should not make much difference to the total at present. However given the increasing importance of storage we hope to take it into account more fully in our model shortly.
methodology.guaranteesOfOrigin-question: What are green certificates, and how are they taken into account?
methodology.guaranteesOfOrigin-answer:
When producers of renewable energy produce electricity, they can create Guarantees of Origin (or Renewable Energy Certificates) - a proof that renewable electricity has been produced and distributed into the power grid. These guarantees can then be sold, giving electricity retailers a way to claim that the electricity they resell comes from renewable sources, regardless of its actual, physical source.

This means that electricity consumers can be told that their electricity comes from solar and wind, even in a windless night. This is problematic, as it removes consumer incentives to consume electricity at the best time (for instance when the amount of renewable electricity in the grid is actually at its highest). This map therefore excludes Guarantees of Origin, instead offering a location-based physical picture of the power grid, in order to empower consumers.
methodology.otherSources-question: Why don‚Äôt you show other sources of emissions than electricity production?
methodology.otherSources-answer: We only focus on electricity production for now, as this is the largest source of emissions and the one that can be most easily decarbonized.
methodology.homeSolarPanel-question: What if I have a solar panel installed in my home?
methodology.homeSolarPanel-answer: We measure the carbon intensity of the local power grid, so any electricity you consume directly from your solar panel (off-grid) is not a part of our measurements. However, if your solar panel is providing power to your local power grid, its production is included in our statistics in areas where estimations of local solar energy production is made publically available (such as in France and in the UK).
methodology.emissionsPerCapita-question: Why don't you show emissions per capita?
methodology.emissionsPerCapita-answer: Some of the electricity consumed in an area is used for manufacturing physical goods and products which are later exported and consumed in other areas. This manufacturing, and therefore also its electricity consumption and associated emissions, are driven by the consumption of products in the importing areas, not in the area where the production is taking place. We believe people should only be responsible for what they consume, not for products manufactured in the area they live in that they do not consume it themselves. In this sense, showing per capita emissions of electricity consumption for areas is misleading.

data.dataOrigins-question: How do you get your data?
data.dataOrigins-answer: We compute all of our data from publically available data, published by electricity grid operators, official agencies, and others. You can click on an area to see more specifics on the origins of its data.
data.dataDownload-answer: We publish data for the past years for free at our Data Portal. For more recent and real-time data you can use our API, which is free for non-commercial use and available for purchase for commercial use.
data.dataIntegration-question: Can I integrate your data real-time into my application or device?
data.dataIntegration-answer: Yes! We provide a free API for non-commercial uses, and sell access to a real-time API for commercial use, which includes forecasts and more.

aboutUs.whoAreYou-answer: The app is developed and maintained by Electricity Maps, a Danish startup company. Our mission is to organise the world's electricity data to drive the transition towards a truly decarbonised electricity system.
aboutUs.feedback-question: Can I give you some feedback?
aboutUs.feedback-answer: We would love that! Please fill out our feedback form.
aboutUs.contribute-question: Can I contribute to your project?
aboutUs.contribute-answer: Yes! The app is an open-source project, made possible by our volunteer contributors. If you want to help develop the map, either by adding data sources for new areas, adding new features or fixing bugs, feel free to join us in our GitHub.
aboutUs.workTogether-answer: We are always looking for new opportunities to collaborate. Send us an email!
aboutUs.disclaimer-answer:
Electricity Maps publishes data and images on the Electricity Maps App for information purposes. It makes no claims of correctness nor provides any form of warranties, and reserves the right to change the content at any time or to remove parts without having to inform you of this. Electricity Maps assumes no responsibility for, and shall not be liable for, any damages or expenses you may incur as a result of any inaccuracy, incompleteness, untimeliness or obsolescence of the Electricity Maps App, or the information derived from them. It is not allowed to include this webpage, or any of its individual elements, in another webpage, without formal prior written consent.

All intellectual property rights belong to the rightful owners and its licensors. Copying, distribution and any other use of these materials, in particular the energy data, is not permitted without the written permission of Electricity Maps, except and only to the extent otherwise provided in regulations of mandatory law (such as the right to quote), unless specified otherwise for specific materials.

This disclaimer may be updated from time to time.
